There's a truly amazing film in here, but due to the film's attitude of trying to embellish its emotional impact and leave our faces tear-stained, it's kind of deluded.

Title: Great stuff
Review:
I had already watched this film in German language before I watched it in my English lessons in English, of course. Perhaps, I was too young when I watched the film for the first time. But now I've realised what a great story it is. It makes you think about yourself: "Do I think on my own or do I just repeat what the "HOI POLLOI" tells me? All in all the movie is great but there's one problem I'd like to mention: Mr Keating makes his pupils do what he wants.

Christine, Pforzheim

Title: Praise for the film Dead Poets Society
Review:
Dead Poets Society is the best movie I have ever seen. I never get bored to it, I have seen it already 8 times. My husband bought me it as DVD for Christmas present, that I would not break the VCR (by playing my old VHS-tape again and again).

Dead Poets Society is absolutely fantastic. Same time touching, sad, funny and fair story about boys, who live in an old, traditional boarding school. A story, how parents are trying to influence for children´s decisions about their career.

For my opinion, Robin Williams and Ethan Hawke played here the best roles of their career.

Title: "Seize the day... make your lives extraordinary!"
Review:
There have been many excellent movies dealing with the theme of teacher/ student interaction: 'To Sir With Love', 'Children of a Lesser God', 'Educating Rita', etc. In most cases the plot revolves around the teacher using special methods to reach students in difficult learning situations, or the teacher becomes a role model or inspiration for the student, or perhaps both, as is the case in 'Dead Poet's Society'.

And I suppose we can all think back to a special teacher who helped us at school, who put in that extra effort to forge a personal connection, and who really seemed to care. Maybe it was an English teacher who introduced us to a special poet or poem? Perhaps a film like this helps us remember these things about our own past, and that is part of the movie's appeal.

'Dead Poet's Society' is about a gifted teacher (played by the inimitable Robin Williams) and a special student, the connection they had, and the disastrous consequences which resulted. It's a uplifting film, a poignant film, a film that touches the heart.

'Dead Poet's Society' was directed by Australian-born Peter Weir who more recently directed 'The Truman Show' and 'Master and Commander'.

Title: My captain oh captain
Review: Robin steals the show as the rebel tacher to a strict college.Ethan Hawk is also good in onee of his first roles.Possibly Weirs best film so far.

Title: The GOAT of high school dramas
Review:
This is the greatest high school drama film of all time, bar none. The storylines for each character intersect in a streamlined and perfect manner, drawing you deep into the lives of these boys who lived a privileged life, financially, but who are crying out for a male role model who will guide and inspire them.

That man is Mr Keating. Williams is faultless in this role. Engaging, warm, intelligent with a sense of humanity that makes him come to life through your screen.

If only we all could have had Mr Keating as our English teachers, we would be better for it.

Title: "O Captain! My Captain!"
Review:
Robin Williams to me is beyond brilliant as the new English teacher John Keating at an all-male prep school Welton Academy. The year is 1959 and we follow a group of boys who are trying to figure out their course in life. Keating does an exceptional job in letting them direct it themselves. The students learn that Keating who once attended the school was part of a group called The Dead Poets Society which this group of boys re-establish under the cover of darkness. Of course nothing is quite that easy as there are major problems that arise during the telling of the story and I don't want to delve into them as I think as a viewer you should watch and experience them yourself. I will say though that it does get heartbreaking.

This is my favourite Robin Williams film and was one of the first that I really watched or at least really remember from back in my childhood. I think I may have been 10 the first time I saw it and was blown away right on my initial viewing. Directed by Peter Weir who has got a great line of films he directed, this just being one of them. The cast also includes Ethan Hawke as Todd Anderson and Robert Sean Leonard as Neil Perry who play roommates and sort of the two main characters within the group of boys, but really none of them take a backseat as they are all different and very well acted. Kurtwood Smith also plays Neil's father.

Title: This is why movies exist
Review:
If an alien came to earth and asked me to choose 1 movie to show him, this would be it. The best movie i've even seen without a shadow of a doubt. I could watch it time and time again.

It's both nostalgic and original, beautiful and tragic, cozy and a call to action not to live your life idly waiting. The movie feels like a beautiful poem. Like it was sitting on the writers chest waiting to be written. It features amazing performances from all, especially Robin Williams.

I never write reviews, but this movie is the one exception. I could 100 reviews and still find new reasons to watch this. Truly, this is ART.

Title: Right
Review: Probably nobody will ever read this. I don't care. I want just to say this: i am a teacher and i know what it means. Great movie. (but IMDB wants a minimum of length, so this additional blurb is just to fill it in - consider my comment ended at "movie")

Title: I recommend that anyone who has not seen "The Dead Poets Society" should see it...
Review: "Dead Poets Society" is one of the most awesome movies I have ever seen! I recommend that anyone who has not seen it should see it; usually people of about 13 years and up, though I first saw it before I was that old. Very deep, emotional, and powerful movie with amazing, wonderful acting. There are boys in a boarding school, not all of whom really want to be there, and they all have emotions dreams that need to be released and lived out. Most of them have been taught and controlled to listen to their parents and follow strict rules of conformity all of their lives. A new English teacher comes to their school with a different way of teaching, trying to push the boys past conformity to feel their personal passion and live out their dreams, in order to express themselves and make a difference in life. There are many other people in the boys' lives (teachers, parents, etc.) that do not agree with what the teacher suggests and teaches to the boys. The two opinions of how the boys should be treated and taught fight a battle at the school and the results and effects of the battle will change the boys' lives forever.

Title: Fun on the surface ,&very meaningful & touching at its depth
Review: Okay. So i came across this movie from a suggestion by my best friend, ishani. We always suggests movies to each other which are mostly fun.. So i thought this would be too.. Yeah see the poster i mean it looks fun ,a teacher changes or how he impacts the life of his students.. And by that impression I watched it... Thinking that it would be a light watch... But oh my, I don't think that I have ever cried or been so emotional, relatable, touched all at the same time while watching something on tv. I was literally crying my hearts out.. This movie does gives some valuable lesson.. Such as following ur passion always and fight for it.. And never ever submit to that fear fight with it... This movie has amazing poetries.. Especially blanket one.. It's every lines, poems have sooo much meaning... Although I would never forgive my friend for suggesting me this film.... But yeas I'll be thankful to her that she suggested such a touching, heart wrenching yet a good watch gem to me. I'm giving 9 because really I wanted something different at last 30 mins.. Realllyyyyyy... Don't wanna give spoilee alerts.. That's why can't say much about what I wanted towards the end... I loved the film but yeah it made me cry a lot.. But I suggest you should watch this... And Robert Sean Leonard is looking soo good ... If nothing else go watch for him... Nd yeah totallly loved todd's relationship with Neil... And yeah one last thing... I hateeee cameronnnnnnnn.... My suggestion : Go watch it CAPTAIN enought of diving into the reviews.

Title: Robin Williams is not the teacher we all need in our lives, but the teacher we all deserve
Review:
Dead Poets Society is an inspiring movie about creative thinking, individuality and the dangers of conformity. A very engaging and entertaining movie that's driven by its beautifully written characters and outstanding performances. It's a great inside look at the expensive preparatory boarding schools that exist in our country and how exclusive they are. Peter Weir is a wizard with visuals. That shot of all the different birds flocking when the school bell rings was great - there's some symbolism there. The way he films landscapes is magical. Great filming locations in this movie. Robin Williams is incredible in this movie, it is without a doubt one of his best roles. He represents not only the teacher we all want in our lives growing up, but the teacher we all need. The teacher everyone deserves. Someone that challenges us, breaks the rules and makes us think outside the box. Robin really was a special gem of a person. One of the most inspiring, influential, uplifting and funny people to ever walk this Earth. Truly a beautiful, witty and intelligent human being. I hope wherever he is, he's in a better place and happy.

The way everything is presented in this movie - the story, the way it flows, the dialogue, the chemistry between everyone, its messages - is perfection. Each character has their own distinct personality and characteristics from the other. They feel like real people, not written characters for a movie. This makes the movie feel alive. A beautifully shot movie with a keen attention to framing and atmosphere. Peter Weir has this beautiful way of shooting certain scenes that make them feel mystical, almost surreal. That shot of the boys running through night fog in their hooded cloaks was exactly that. The way he can capture that element of mysticism is something remarkable, it's something very rare and not seen in movies. Definitely sets him apart from other directors.

Robin teaches us to find our own individuality, identity and inner voice that makes us unique. He challenges us to question things (like the system and rules put in place), to find meaning where there might not be and most importantly to believe in ourselves and follow our passion. That whole sequence with the chanting monks in the background and Neil after his father tells him about military school was so haunting, ominous and hypnotic - incredibly done. You just knew something bad was going to happen. It's like the entire tone of the movie changes. A shocking and sobering reminder that parents can change their kids lives, sometimes not for the best - even if their intentions are good. It's sad really, because Neil knew what he loved, he knew what his passion was and what he wanted to do. This is a lesson to be learned by all parents.

A magnificent, inspiring, meaningful and impactful film. A must-watch.

Title: Carpe Diem
Review:
This is one of the greatest achievements in all of film. Robin Williams gives a performance that is his most memorable. He plays John Keating, an English teacher who inspires a group of young men in his poetry class to seize the day (carpe diem). He teaches the boys the beauty of poetry and the human soul.

The performances in this film are extraordinary. From Williams to Robert Sean Leonard to Ethan Hawke.This movie is as touching as it is wonderful. Movies like this are the reason we have cinema in the first place. It is a truly captivating and breath-taking picture. My compliments to Peter Weir (Who was totally deserving of the Academy Award for Best Director for this movie). An A++++ in my book.

Title: Amazing in every way
Review: If you haven't watched it, go do it right now. If you have, you'll appreicate everything that went into this amazing movie.

Title: The Best Ever
Review: This has to be one of my favorite movies ever. I think that it is the most classic example of an English Major movie. Robin Williams is phenomenal in this movie. He portrays the quintessential English teacher, quirky and eccentric. His character Mr. Keating, is one of those teachers who everyone loves, he's the teacher that you go to with anything, even if you don't' have him for a class. As an English Major I feel that this movie helps to show the beauty and the wonder that is English literature. The way that it is presented just seems to open the world of literature into mainstream. It invites people to go read Byron, Shelley, and Wordsworth. For me, it makes people want to read the classics, it is one of the things in this world that I think helps me to remember why, when I'm down having to read and dissect obscure literature, I chose to be an English major. It helps you to as Keating says "think for your self". Its a movie for everyone despite what I've said, because you take the message and it translates into anything, "think for your self". If I had to say anything about that I would say it was the moral of the story. Its helping to show people that they don't' have to be sheep, that they can think with out following the paved road. Carpe Diem, Seize the Day, for me this movie represents everything that I, as an English Major want to help show the world.

Title: I cried... a lot.
Review:
Objectively speaking, this movie isn't a 10, but I don't give a damn, this movie came to me at the perfect time in my life. I was sobbing through the entire third act. That feeling when you can't be who you are, because you don't want to disappoint who you love, is something I've been wrestling with my entire life. Becoming mentally ill because hiding the person you really are causes you to lose any sense of self, as if you are slowly disintegrating into an automated copy of who others think you are. Every beat of this film reached deep within me and pulled out all the anxiety and depression that festers at the bottom of my heart and told me to just breeeeeathe. We must not fall to the fate of Neil. This movie is truly beautiful and should be shown to every parent who thinks they are the writers of their children's destiny's. They still would not change but at least they'll have a different perspective.

Stay true to who you are, pursue your dreams, because life is too silly not to.

Title: CARPE DIEM!!
Review: This movie is definitely in my top 10. It's a great story, and I have never seen surroundings so beautiful. This is Robin Williams absolute BEST performance ever. (Robert Sean Leonard and Ethan Hawke are great too.) It is a truly inspirational story and I never tire of seeing it. CARPE DIEM!!!

Title: A very rare 10/10
Review: It's very rare that I give a movie a true 10/10. To give a movie a 10/10 is to imply that this movie moved me, that it changed my perspective on something, that it left me wondering and still thinking about it hours after watching it. When I first watched this movie, I had no clue what it was about. To be honest, it had no value to me. I read the description and I almost clicked away but something drew me to this movie. This movie never ceases to make me cry and leave me in a trance, and for that it gets a 10/10. The life lessons taught in this movie can be applied to any situation in life and continue to help me in the situations that arise in my life.

Title: Was expecting better after the hyped reviews.
Review: I had heard this film was a classic and was expecting to get drawn in and mesmorised by an amazing story. Sadly an hour into the film I failed to see the hype. The issue, was it just appeared to be a flat boring story about some well behaved kids of privelege at a school where an unorthodox English teacher who enthusiastically opens their minds and views to how poetry is romantic and can "change the world" with all that Carpe DM BS... sorry but in the real world iv seen alot of people that are still holding onto that attitiude "live for today don't think about tomorrow" are alcoholic, skint, singletons... Anyway I digress... the kids believe every word of it without argument and the plot never really went anywhere, the kids were neither rebellious nor transformed in their attitudes by poetry. It was just boring. I just failed to see what was so amazing about it.

Title: Its interesting and entertaining but never brilliant
Review:
My Rating: *** out of ****.

Dead Poets Society is a good film but it was swept up by the academy. This is one of those times where the academy nominates something that is undeserving. Dead Poets Society was nominated for four academy awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Robin Williams), and Best Original Screenplay. Out of those four, one of them may have been deserving.

The acting is solid throughout the film. Robin Williams gives a solid, convincing performance as John Keating. Yet, even know he is good here he did not deserve a nomination for Best Actor. For one thing, the performance is nothing amazing and he actually does not have a whole lot of screentime.

The best acting comes from the supporting players, who are the kids in the school. The best performance comes from Ethan Hawke. He gives an excellent portrayal as a shy, unassured teenager. The rest of the acting from the teenagers is all solid.

The Dead Poet Society is always interesting and entertaining but it never striked me as brilliant. Its a well written movie and it has its share of good moments but never really rises above. The movie does look great visually. The Cinematography is excellent. A Peter Weir movie (the director) always looks great.

However, the Dead Poets Sociey has flaws. Was it ever really necessary to have a subplot about them going into the Dead Poets Society? That subplot seemed really pointless. Also, there was a scene when one of the kids commits suicide. The music seemed somewhat pretentious during this moment. As did some of the shots. Why did the camera focus on the Dads slippers then? Whats the significance? Peter Weir has been accused of being pretentious at times and that whole moment seemed pretentious. Peter Weir has done better (Witness, Master and Commander).

Even with its flaws, I still liked Dead Poets Society. It was overrated by the academy but that does not make it a bad movie. Its a good film, its just not great.

Title: A Coming of Age Story as Good as "The Cider House Rules" and "Scent of a Woman"
Review:
When this movie ended I was speechless. This is honestly one of the BEST movies I have ever seen. I was looking at some reviews of this movie and I saw that some people gave this movie horrible ratings. This movie is a true masterpiece. I really don't understand how some people can give this movie a 1/10.

I really don't understand why this movie is not on the top 250. It should at least be in the 100's. I think that this is probably Robin William's 2nd best performance behind "Good Will Hunting." I also think that all his students like Ethan Hawk did a great job too.

I honestly thought that this movie was A MASTERPIECE.

Title: struggle for self-expression
Review: Great and atmospheric movie. The film reveals such a deep theme as freedom, the struggle for self-expression and the struggle against the system. Good performance from Robin Williams.

Title: Tragedy was to show others the process of ruining the valuable things.
Review: Tragedy was to show others the process of ruining the valuable things. Neil was such a dynamic, and pure boy. When I saw his death, I felt something choked in my throat. He known what 'captain 'was talking about, his heart was full of passion to life, to art, to freedom. But how can a little bird against the stubborn system? I commented this movie was a tragedy not only Neil, but other's fates. I really loved the character Todd, who was much like most of us, not much colorful. When I heard of his poem about truth, I paused it, and read loudly it. I had to admit it was such a pottery one that I was shocked at that time. but who had inspired him might never appear in his life. What happened to other students? I remembered at the end of this movie, one of them said: they just wanted a victim, why let Keating ruin our life?' yes, after all these happinesses, life would always back to peaceful desperation. But I believe words and ideas would change the world, and those people would never be at gray area, because they're called heterogeneous

Title: This Movie Changed My Life
Review:
Okay, so that's a pretty big statement, but out of all the films I've seen in my life, this film is one that I can point to changing it. Some of it must have had to do when I saw it, teenager, and the typical teenager things I was going through.

For one, I started writing and reading poetry. If that isn't enough of a change I became a literature major in College. This film gave me courage to do crazy things, to step out of my shell and to actually ask girls out instead of thinking about them all the time. It affected my view of art, and that it's okay to be an artist and still be male.

I think it is an excellent coming of age film for boys, it goes through so many of the emotions rattling around inside during that time. The joy, uncertainty, pressure to fit in, attraction, betrayal, wanting love from a parent but never getting it and on and on.

I've seen this film enough times to see the flaws but I love every minute of it, flaws and all. There is so much subtly in the film that goes unnoticed.

When Keating tells the boys to rip the page out of a book, the Judas of the group uses a ruler to rip the page out but leaving a thin strip of the page in the book. A metaphor for when he betrays the others.

After reading some of the comments on this site, specifically the ones that pointed out why none of the beat poets were in the film, I came to the conclusion that it is interesting that the poetry studied in this film is full of structure. All the poems read were written in a strict poetical form, with the exception of Wadsworth. Structure is not devoid of beauty, just as chaos is not devoid of patterns. More often than not, it is structure that allows beauty to bloom. And although Keating was encouraging the boys to break out of the mold, to think for themselves, at one point when Neuwanda places a phone call to God in a school gathering, he cautions the boys to suck the marrow out of life, just don't choke on the bone.

I don't think the purpose of the film is that all structure is evil, but instead to find your passion, whatever it is. There can be beauty and passion in crunching numbers as much as painting starry nights.

Title: awful
Review: This movie is quite a boring film. We were made to watch it in English and it was a very boring film. The teacher also asked to write a movie review on this film but most of the class had no idea what the film was about. The teacher also asked us to spend our money to rent the film and watch it. i would rate it 0 but you don't have it!!!! all up this is an awful film. I would never watch this film again it was an outright disgrace i would not watch it if it was the last film on earth including Cinderella story i'm still having night mares about that one lol (laugh out loud) I'm being very serious about this (not the nightmares the movie) it is downright an absolute outrage.

Title: The best coming of age film I've seen
Review: The battle cry for youth looking to branch out against societal norms: carpe diem. It is the best coming of age film I've ever seen or know of. It invokes emotion and passion and motivates you to look at your own life to see if you've settled in areas you shouldn't. I've seen it over a dozen times now and it gets better each time I watch it as I catch more subtleties.

Title: A lesson for life
Review:
A film made more than 30 years ago about the time 70 years ago, and it is very applicable today.

People are put into molds, their lives, careers, professions are planned, and these young people do what is expected of them, not what they want. Free opinion is almost forbidden. It is enough to follow the young guys from the film who are all equally dressed, have the same things, room, objects, but as soon as you put them together, it is easy to see how each of them is completely different and is a special individual. And then when someone jumps out of someone's projection, expectation, or mold, then that person is looked at strangely, as if he is not normal. The whole education system is based on that, creating accurate and the same molds from people who are completely different, have different affinities, traits and desires. When a teacher appears who does not want to shape young minds in this way, but shows them the path they can take, which inspires them and shows them the possibilities, that same teacher looks strange and abnormal.

I have to admit that flaw of the film is that this is not the first time I have seen Robin Williams in similar roles, but the character is simply so nicely suited that it is impossible to imagine someone else who will show a great measure and combination of humor, seriousness, inspiration and sadness. The ending of the film was so emotional and perfectly rounded to me which is proof that the director succeeded in his plan because otherwise I am not a person who reacts to films like that.

Title: A good movie
Review:
Dead Poets Society is a drama movie which takes place in the late 1950s in the United-States. The story is set in a renowned boys-only preparatory school called Welton Academy, which is traditional, austerre and where the students are expected to be the best. A group of boys formed by Neil Perry, played by Robert Sean Leonard (who plays Dr Wilson in Dr House), Todd Anderson played by Ethan Hawke, Know Overstreet played by Josh Charles and others.

There are new English teacher, Mr keating (played by Robin Williams). He's an unusual teacher as his way to teach isn't the same as the other teachers. He talks to the student about an old secret organization : the Dead Poets Society, a poets group. The Boys decide to recreate this group and it will change their lives because they'll want to seize the day and they'll learn how to think for themselves, but it's maybe not a good thing for them and Mr keating.

I like this film because I love film because it's about school and relations between teachers, children and parents.

The movie had the Oscar for best screenplay.

Title: O Captain! My Captain!
Review: Dead Poets Society hits you like a truck. It is so powerful that it will move you, inspire you, make you think. Exactly what Professor Keating (Robin Williams) did to his students. "Boys, you must strive to find your own voice" and of course "Carpe Diem" are two phrases that capture the essence of his philosophy. In other words, find your passion and go for it without wasting your time on what society or the rules consider right. From that moment on, his students' lives are changed forever. Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) wants to become an actor, Todd Anderson (Ethan Hawke) wants to overcome his insecurity and come to terms with himself, Knox Overstreet (Josh Charles) wants to capture the heart of a girl he met and Charlie Dalton (Gale Hansen), perhaps the most committed practitioner of Mr. Keating's teachings, wants to turn the world upside down and in the meantime have as much fun as possible. Another great thing about it is that it shows both sides of the coin, namely that even if you get in this state of mind, life works in mysterious ways and there are no guarantees of success or happiness, reality can crush you at any moment. All in all, it's hard to judge Dead Poets Society purely as a movie, it's more of a life experience.

Title: Beautiful
Review: More meaningful and purposeful than any movie that I have ever seen, except for the Truman Show. Really shows the purpose of life and how you should live it. Also has some educational moments where you actually learn something. If you don't have an open mind and a really low attention span, you probably wont appreciate Dead Poets Society as much as others. It all really depends on your point of view. But I think that this is a work of art

Title: Sweaty-Toothed Mad Man Society
Review:
----- And the human race is filled with passion. And medicine, law, business, engineering, these are noble pursuits and necessary to sustain life. But poetry, beauty, romance, love, these are what we stay alive for.

-----

"Dead Poets Society" is one of the few films that have shaped my perception of the world. I'm so glad I watched this film.

How is this a 1989 movie? This film is still relevant today, and we crave academic validation and follow routines and discipline to the point where we have killed our creativity. It's rare to find artists and *poets*, like these in real life. We need to make this film mandatory to all!

To summarise, this movie is about a group.of elite students attending Welton Academy (or "Hellton") who conform to the strict norms of the school. However, when a new English teacher named Mr Keating comes along, their perception of the world slowly changes. Mr Keating teaches them to be their own unique character and think creatively. They do things they have never thought of before. The consequences shortly follow.

Every scene of the film is masterfully crafted. There are some specific shots that make for awesome desktop backgrounds. The music, suspense, and all other theatrical effects are WAY ahead of the movie's age. The characters are unique and feel real to me.

We need more movies like this that depict valuable morals. God bless Robin Williams, Neil, Todd, Charlie, Knox, and Peter Weir himself.

Title: This is the best movie ever made. Period.
Review:
That is a very strong claim to make, and as you all can see (for those of you who HAVE seen this great film), I am so enamored of it that when DPS came out 9 1/2 years ago, I casually picked up the nickname "Neuanda" (chosen by one Charlie Dalton, a character in the film), and haven't let go of it since.

It is extremely important to tell all of you who have not seen this movie that your experience with DPS will not remotely mirror what I went through when I first encountered it. Some of you will love it, some of you will loathe it, while others, still, will have mixed reactions.

And that is the beauty of it (and the beauty of moviedom, in general).

I was 15 years old and emotionally poised to receive a movie of this calliber. I was young enough for it to become a part of my still malleable soul, and old enough to understand the gravity of its message . I can only hope that something similar will happen for all of you who have yet to see it. The movie's message is a simple one, but profound and enlightening, just the same. Please take the 2+ hours to experience it, and relate it to your life the best way you know how. That is all I can ask.

Carpe Diem and Enjoy.

Title: !!!CARPE DIEM INDEED!!!
Review: I will make this very short since I always find it difficult to put into words(in this case writing) when I encounter a wonderful experience. "Dead Poets Society" is the biggest inspiration I ever saw put on film and I couldn't have seen it at a better time because I am exactly at this point in my life. I am becoming the master of my destiny and this movie made me believe in my path even more. Robin William's performance of a lifetime and the rest of the cast is just as superb!!! Thank you boys.

Title: "Captain, my captain!"
Review:
If you say that is Robin Williams' best film ever, and without doubt one of his best performances, you will not hear me object to it! Cause I would agree. Williams does a magnificent job. Because usually he covers his characters with too much funny faces and joking around, so that it gets a bit tiring after a while. But in "Dead Poets Society", he masterfully combines his genious comedy-talent with his more serious side of acting and it's a winning combination.

Peter Weir's directing is awesome, and the combination of a great story, excellent acting from all actors involved, solid camerawork and both humour and drama, makes this one of my all time highs!

Title: Ode to Freedom : The Timeless Brilliance of Dead Poets Society
Review:
In the tapestry of cinematic masterpieces, Peter Weir's Dead Poets Society emerges as a lyrical sonnet, a celebration of literary and poetic flavors that enchants the soul. A film so magnificent, it illuminates the path to emancipation from societal dogmas, embodying the fervent desire of adolescents to break free - free from familial constraints, free from societal conformity, free to be authentically themselves.

This cinematic gem is not merely a film; it is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of art, a profound reflection on life, freedom, and the essence of true education. At its heart, Dead Poets Society is an ode to liberation, an exploration of the delicate balance between conformity and individualism, presented through the lens of a group of young students guided by the charismatic litterature teacher, Professor John Keating.

Professor Keating, portrayed with unparalleled brilliance by Robin Williams, is the linchpin of the film's narrative, a maestro leading his students on a journey of self-discovery and free thought. His passion for literature becomes a catalyst for emancipation, a rebellion against the conventional norms upheld by the school's dean.

The film navigates the tumultuous waters of conflicting educational philosophies, where the dean, an advocate of rigid scholastic protocols, stands in stark contrast to Professor Keating's visionary approach. The professor yearns to nurture free-thinking minds, urging his students to think for themselves, to make the study of literature a tangible and transformative experience.

'Can one think for oneself when young?' is a central question posed by the film. It extends beyond the confines of the school, echoing the universal journey everyone must undertake between the sheltered environment of academia and the harsh realities of the outside world. The film subtly critiques the submission to various constraints - be they ideological, familial, social, or political - reflecting a poignant fatalism that questions whether true freedom is the ability to do anything or the desire to embrace what one can.

For me, Dead Poets Society etches an indelible mark as one of the finest cinematic creations, transcending the screen to become a contemplation on freedom, conformity, and the eternal quest for self-identity. It probes into the depths of our souls, prompting us to ponder - who are we, and who do we aspire to become? How can one navigate the labyrinth of societal constraints while finding happiness and fulfillment in personal choices?

This film encapsulates a timeless and impassioned debate, weaving a touching and thought-provoking narrative. Dead Poets Society stands as a cinematic marvel, a beacon of humanism, drama, and beauty that proudly claims its place in my top five. It's a treasure I'll revisit time and again, for it encapsulates all I hold dear today: poetry, theater, literature - a symphony that resonates with the chords of liberation.

Title: Discovering Yourself and Living Life to the Fullest: A Review of 'Dead Poets Society'
Review: "Dead Poets Society" is a drama film from 1989 and was directed by Peter Weir. Its main characters are played by Robin Williams, Ethan Hawke, Robert Sean Leonard, and Josh Charles. The movie tells the story of an unusual English teacher, John Keating, who teaches his students to think for themselves. The movie is visually pleasing, and the actors deliver great portrayals of their characters. The characters in "Dead Poets Society" have great character development and are all different to each other, each character has their own unique personalities and problems to overcome. Robin Williams plays his character, John Keating, very good. He teaches, like mentioned above, his students to think for themselves and to do what fulfils them. Ethan Hawke, Robert Sean Leonard, and Josh Charles perform great as Keating's students. All of them have issues they have to deal with and have a lot of pressure on them. The supporting cast is also great, adding depth and more emotion to the film. What makes "Dead Poets Society" truly great is its message of embracing individuality and taking risks to fulfil yourself. Its catchphrase "carpe diem" translates roughly to "seize the day". It means you should take risks to fulfil yourself, before it is too late. The film shows how important education is, because it is able to change a person completely, and the importance of seizing them when given opportunities. You can tell that that is a good message, since most people, us included, think that "Carpe diem. Seize the day, boys. Make your lives extraordinary.", said by John Keating is the best quote from the movie. If you love great storytelling, "Dead Poets Society" is a must-see film that will leave a lasting impact.

Title: Seize the moment
Review:
Ah, a superb classic. I watched "Dead Poets Society" because, well, I was bored. And I wanted to watch a movie I'd assume would put me asleep, well, actually I stayed up to watch it. The story is very excellent. And with fantastic actors such as Robin Williams, Robert Sean Leonard, and Ethan Hawke. I would recommend this wonderful drama to anyone.

8/10

Title: Why won't they make movies like these anymore?
Review: The thing I love most about this movie is the script. From the story and dialogue. The actors, director and crew did a great job. Now I know I'm late just watching this film now but it is now my favorite movie.

Title: not a "must-see"
Review: I know a lot of people consider this movie to be a classic but I found it to be just sappy for the sake of sap and a complete lack of any humor. For that I don't see this as a "must-watch" so much as a "must-know" because the film did produce so many catch-phrases that we hear in pop-culture such as "oh captain my captain."

Title: Oh captain! my captain !
Review:
Dead Poets Society is a drama film set in Vermont, New England in the late 1950s in which we follow the story of Todd Anderson a painfully socially anxious boy who's transferred to the well-reputed Welton Academy, his new social butterfly roommate, Neil Perry, and their friend group.

As the school year begins they are introduced to their new unorthodox English teacher, Mr. Keating, who's played by the famous actor Robin Williams. The teacher along with his surprising methods will change the boy's perception of life through poetry and push them into seizing the day.

This drama is my absolute favorite film. I love the message behind it, live for the day because you could die any day without ever having the guts to accomplish anything. I don't think I could bring myself to choose a favorite character because they're all so endearing. I loved watching Todd's self-development throughout the movie and the rest of the group's change of way of life. Sadly it isn't a happy movie but the sad part of it was necessary for the characters' development and makes it the wonderful, life-changing film Dead Poets Society is.

Title: best lines
Review:

When i had come to die discovered that i had not lived

Title: Tugs on you heart strings.
Review:
This film was something that tugs on your heart strings. The way it shows you to be yourself and to do what you love and enjoy it to your full potential. It also shows that having a good teacher who genuinely believes in you and what you want to do is so important in giving you the courage and resilience to do what you love.

Robin Williams has done it again, showing what a great actor he is and he is such a father figure to so many young kids. His character 'Mr Keating' inspires his students to seize the day through his love of poetry. He shows that its perfectly normal to be passionate about your hobbies, telling his students to grab what makes them tick and never to let go of it.

Title: What a movie.
Review: I won't say much, but this movie profoundly affected me. The boys, the teacher, the things they went through. It gave me the deepest thoughts to ever transpire in the wake of a film. I still think about it in a somber mood today. From how Robin Williams simply excelled in the role to how I can only see each boy in that one role. Their scenes, quotes, some things still just resonate with me. Even if you don't enjoy one of the actors, or this type of a film. I would consider it a must watch, just to make the most of your life, and see something that it really, truly, a masterpiece. 10/10 for everything.

Title: Touching but not enough
Review: When I watched this movie for the first time, I was looking for a job as a teacher. I was very moved and wanted to be a teacher like Mr. Keating. Complying with the students' nature will make people feel empathy and respect; in contrast, we are usually limited by many rules against our natural desire. But now, after being a teacher for many years and studying postgraduate education courses, I think the film is more about opposing education theories confrontation with less positive communication. Mr. Keating's idea about "learn to think for yourself" is a valuable limited resource in many classrooms. But it became the only learning content, deviating from society and reality, it is also problematic. In the film, Mr. Keating asked the students to tear up all the poems related to realism, which is avoiding further discussion between reality and human nature. If these conflicts of ideas cannot be considered in the curriculum to develop more profound and complex understandings, then these conflicts will be reflected in the real lives of students and teachers. It caused the tragedy in this movie.

Title: This movie is an inspiration
Review: Dead Poet's Society has everything necessary for an exceptional movie. First, an Oscar winning screen play. Second, an exceptional cast Robin Williams is a great actor and was paired with Ethan Hawke this combination is incredible. Lastly, a director meant to blow your socks off Peter Wier knew exactly where to go with this any one who hasn't seen this movie must see it (NOW). This movie inspires everyone to get up and do, "to suck all the marrow out of life." This is truly a movie for all it has a little language and a few sexual innuendos, but that is nothing to be taken into consideration.

Title: almost as good as sky high(2005)
Review: This is my favorite autumn movie. It's heart wrenching, and the ending makes me mad. Red forman was really pissing me off. Also, neil and todd were definitely in love and you cant change my mind.

Title: Fantastic
Review:
One of the most striking movies I have ever seen. The characters are written beautifully and you grow to love them quite early on. Before watching this film I read the book, which was also beautiful and which I definitly recommend.

I think everyone, especially parents and teachers, should watch this movie. It can teach you new things and show you another persons' perspective. I cried my eyes out and wish I can re-experience watching/reading this story for the first time again.

Side note: beautifull cinematography and aesthetics throughout this movie. I wish we had more films like this. Simply beautiful!

Title: Remarkable Storyline
Review: Where do i even begin? I, myself being an English major student hadn't watched this film earlier. I was advised by my friends to watch it and i'm so glad i did. I think this is one of those movies which you can call your "comfort" films. The storyline, the acting, the characters, the poetry, the direction, the quotes, literally there's nothing in this film which you can dislike. This is one of the most beautiful films i've seen and i would recommend everyone to watch it. You will not be disappointed. If you love the drama genre and you love poetry, i think you're gonna fall in love with the quotes, setting, characters and the storyline. Overall, this movie is just too good, you have to watch it in order to believe it. This film teaches us so much if we pay attention and the advice they give: "seize the moment" ; just remarkable. From beginning to the end, this move is a true masterpiece.

Title: Outstanding
Review:
Dead Poets Society has got to be one of the best written films I have ever seen. The way the writers are able to control your emotion is insane. You truly go on an emotional ride in this film as a viewer, and will feel ever single emotion there is. The acting is outstanding and it's really rare to see a cast that clearly understands their role in the film and portrays it not only realistically but rememberable. This is one of the few films that I will remember for the rest of my life just because of how good it is. Definitely my favorite Robin Williams movie and I recommend this for everyone.

Overall, 10/10.

Title: Carpe diem. Seize the day, boys. Make your lives extraordinary.
Review:
Dead Poets Society is a 1989 American drama film directed by Peter Weir and starring Robin Williams. The film is set at the conservative and aristocratic Welton Academy in Vermont in 1959. The story follows an English teacher, John Keating, who inspires his students through his unconventional teaching methods and love of poetry.

The film explores themes of individuality, freedom, and the power of the arts to inspire and transform. Through Keating's teachings, the students at Welton Academy learn to think for themselves, to challenge the status quo, and to seize the day. As Keating says in the film, "Carpe diem. Seize the day, boys. Make your lives extraordinary."

One of the most memorable scenes in the film is when Keating leads his students to the school's amphitheater, where they read poetry and express their emotions freely. This scene showcases the transformative power of the arts and the importance of self-expression.

Overall, Dead Poets Society is a powerful and moving film that challenges viewers to think for themselves and to embrace their individuality. It is a celebration of the human spirit and the boundless potential of the young.

Title: One of the best film of all time, for "free thinkers"
Review:
I watched this film the first time when I was 10 or something, but was falling in love with the film when I was 17. The same age of Knox Overstreet, Todd Anderson, and other guys in the movie.

"Dead Poets Society" talks about the lives of the students in the "Welton Academy", an elite prep-school preparing the students to ivy league school. These students were brought up in a strict and mainstream families.

All unexpectedly, the students are exposed to Mr. Keating, an English teacher whose will change their lives through "free-will" thinking.

One of the best film of all time!

Title: The best
Review:
O Captain ! My Captain !

Though Robert Willlams is playing the lead role and I definitely love his character but the character played by Robert Shawn Leonard will made you cry.

Title: Great moving movie
Review: I felt like it talks about me. I love it, I have to admit I think its one of my favorite movies all time. Thank you Robin Williams Rest In Peace. And to Ethan Hawke you are so talented.

Title: An interesting take on the arts in school life, along with the downsides of extreme art addiction
Review:
The film works as a whole as great entertainment and also as an engrossing message to the society. I am not sure what to make of the heavily dramatic climax, does the director want us to love arts? Or is he warning about the burden that comes with loving anything too much? My guess is the later, as he is an artist himself (Cinematic art). The film stays buoyant from the starting to the end, typical of a high school setting and all characters feel natural. The teacher who inspires everyone seems to breathe life into all his fans (students) and increasingly dwells in our hearts as a hero who lets us "live" in this ever-competitive, heartless, unequal world.

Overall, I walked away from the film as a changed man with lifelong repercussions. The movie is labeled as legendary by many others as well and I recommend this wholeheartedly if you like offbeat films about education. The dialogues are lovely and all the interactions between characters are interesting. The film has enough twists and turns to keep us engaged throughout its duration..

Title: Seize the Day!
Review:
Having a strong role model is instrumental in the development in our lives. Whether it's an athletic coach, parent or an English teacher, we are all touched uniquely by those around us.

We are all arguably trying to attain happiness in our lives. This can range from searching for love and exploring the world to volunteering at the local animal shelter. Regardless of "what" we strive to do, it is important to realize we are genuinely interested in fulfilling this void.

Poetry is more than just another form of expression. Language is arguably the strongest tool we as humans have, and is a special talent that can be used to accomplish extraordinary feats. Throughout the education system, students (and even teachers) often begin to forget the purpose and importance of the content being learned.

Enter Mr. Keating.

He is no simple man nor is he carrying a stringent course outline. He allows his students freedom; the chance to realize and fulfil their potential, whatever that means. He encourages his students to explore, understand and seriously think about society and the world we live in. He is an example of what every child deserves...what they need. It is sad to see people live like drones despite the immense opportunities the work has to offer. It is crucial that we learn to seize the day and actually make the most of our lives!

Living your life according to your will and yours alone is a testament that should be widely advocated. Not one where people are necessarily individualistic, no, but one where everyones learns to enjoy every moment of their lives. Why spend your life doing something you don't enjoy? Be passionate and live, since the worst death is one while you're still alive.

Title: Be against something....
Review:
...no matter what.

That is the message of DPS.

This is a pretty dumb, extremely overrated, obnoxiously preachy and for all purposes as far away from reality as the two extremes of the universe.

The funny thing is that the people who write against conformism, are the ones who become millionaires selling these silly ideas in movie theaters.

It took me a while to watch DPS. Well, all these I 've missed nothing.

And Robby Williams (RIP) stinks big time in this one.

Title: Great Movie!
Review: this is the kinda movie that really pump you up I have to say if u want to change your view of life this is the Movie you would appreciate to watch! so i guess if you haven't watched it yet, go to nearest store and buy it and i will guarantee that you will not regret the time nor the money. so have fun watching it. And as a viewer who wont fall in love with any kind of movie i have to say once you watch it you will L O V E this thing because i think this movie got everything that a good movie requires, interesting plot and not cliché at all, and the acting is just great plus there is a wonderful ending and like i said you will love this movie just give it a chance and put a little time, u'll see it for yourselves!

Title: Lived up to the expectations!
Review: Honestly, I watched this movie because Dr. House mentioned about it on the S8E21 of House M.D. When I checked the trivia on IMDB, realised that Wilson was the protagonist in the movie and that got me interested and how could I say no to Robin Williams... Lovely it was. Must watch.

Title: Depressing But Inspiring
Review: "What a terrific movie, terrific perfomance, and terrific story, all in here is just extraordinary, i really enjoyed this so much, i don't even know what i'm gonna write anymore it just already perfect and i don't see anything wrong, overall Dead Poets Society is depressing but very inspiring, i highly recommended"

Title: Seize your day and watch this movie
Review:
From Director Peter Weir (The Truman Show) and screenwriter Tom Schulman (Honey, I shrunk the kids) introducing this classical school melodrama set in the world of "America's best preparatory school" Wilton Academy where the students bearing names like "Pitts" and "Meeks" (you couldn't find whiter names?) are introduced to their new English professor John Keating (Robin Williams) who comes bearing his informal and contemporary teaching methods making him appeal to his new students immediately.

The movie-set in 1959-follows the theme of challenging the conservative, conventional style of life and encouraging a new free thinking style presented by the character of prof. Keating, who, to be honest, didn't take much time getting into the heads of a group of white nerdy boys who do study groups in their first day of school, really lads? Anywho, professor Keating, who keeps constantly quoting Whitman, Herrick, and Tennyson, introduces the boys into the "cute" world of poetry in a very dynamic and playful acting much as the actor himself, losing himself into his theatrical persona where he reads Shakespeare sonnets impersonating Marlon Brando from the godfather (uhmm somebody needs to tell Robin that the godfather deputed 19 years after the time of the movie) but regardless of his outstanding performance as the quick witted, fast paced professor, I'm afraid that Robin Willam's character does not fit as a protagonist of this film rather than the tool that helped the plot move, the character wasn't anything more than a very well crafted plot device in this movie.

The main conflict we see in this movie is between a young Robert Sean Leonard playing the role of Neil, a smart student who dreams of becoming an actor, and his hardheaded strict father who denies him his wishes in fear of it disturbing his education (probably the only white boys in the US who cannot defy their parents) a conflict which ends up in a most tragic way.

The dead poets society is a secret society founded by an intellectual equivalent of a 98 Pound weakling teenage version of professor John Keating himself, and reincarnated by his young students who get immediately attracted to the idea of poetry under the influence of their charismatic teacher, the reincarnated form though, seems to be completely purposeless (well asides from meeting in a cave in the night, wooing chicks with other poets lines and dancing to Vanche Lindsay's "The Congo" (one of the poems that critics debate it's racist content which is ironic in an all white cast movie).

The movie's cast including Robin Willams, Robert S. Leonard, and Ethan Hawke did a great job portraying their roles and quite frankly hiding the many flaws in a movie that has not one, not two but three scenes with birds flying off in one sequence (maybe Peter Weir is trying to compensate for the lack of "birds" in the all boys school?) but all in all the movie is quite enjoyable, entertaining and indeed, worthwhile.

Title: ZzzZzZzzzzz
Review:
ZzzZzzzZZzzzzzZZzzzzzZZzzzZzzzZzZzzzzzz

😴😴😴😴😴

Title: A Williams Wonderpiece!
Review:
Its a terrific story that is completely stolen by Robin Williams's heart.

If you removed him from this movie, people would struggle to remember it, Williams is everything to the Dead Poets Society.

Outstanding.

Title: Spectacular
Review: Dead Poets' Society is by far one of the best movies I have ever witnessed in my 17 years of life. No movie has more impacted my life on a daily basis as this one has. The reflection on what society expects of us that is consistent throughout the entire movie is intriguing and presented in a likable way. This extravagant movie is filled with quotes you will hold onto for a lifetime, helping you to cope with the distressing situations that life will bring. Each character's plot line speaks about another type of existence, proving that we all have our own individual lives. Each person's plot is an extension of the theme that life is more than a career. Each person's hope and dreams are hindered by society and its demands on the individual. An outlet for this stress is the Dead Poets' Society, which is a collective group of boys in the private school. They write poetry and songs, sharing with one another. They express the demands on them as teenagers in this world: "Laughing, crying, tumbling, mumbling, Gotta do more, gotta be more. Chaos screaming, chaos dreaming, Gotta be more, gotta do more." This along with several other lines is what intrigues me most about this movie. The poetry is written so artfully to fit its message, and succeeds wonderfully in this outstanding movie.

Title: Carpe diem
Review:
Seize your day : that's all about I am thinking. Being a procrastinator this movie really hit me to do things and stop to just worrying about them. But but don't do all things recklessly is also stated in there.

From now on all I want is to make sure that I live enough that makes me happy. I am going to Stop Putting people before/above me in my priorities, There I am suppose to be first one What a motivational movie it is!!! Without any high proficiency sports theme.

One more thing special about this movie was it wasn't focused on specific character as past or future of that character it was all started in present and it lived through the present.

One more note:- don't try to add ladies to a beautiful dead poets society. Mandatory!? Yes it is.

Till then Carpe diem.

Title: Dead poet society Movie's review by Khitab Wazir
Review: Dead poet society movie depicts the gruesome face of society and the traditional poor system of academic institutions. These two things play a major role in ruining the life of a creative student. Their creative ability cannot thrive in the presence of these two factors. It has shown in the movie how lots of fathers decide the fate of his son and then how dreadful consequences it might bring. They do not let their sons to decide their own choice. And most importantly how art is considered an absurdity been also shown. The character named "Neil Perry" wants to become an actor but his father does not like it, because art has no value for him. Despite of the reluctance he comes onto the stage and performs the play, in the meantime his father comes and eliminates his son from this school. Neil Perry then commits suicide and embraces death. To be more precise dead poet society movie interprets some bad factors of a society by which a creative boy or girl's life gets ruined. These factors are 1poor school system 2authoritative/Dictator type guardian 3devaluation of art 4restrictions to think openly.

Title: This film made me an English Major :-)
Review: Dead Poet's Society is a delightfully well-crafted coming-of-age film from director Peter Weir who has garnered his most recent notoriety for "Master & Commander: The Far Side of the World." In this film, Weir takes us to a small New England prep-school at the tail end of the 1950's and shows us one school term in the life of a teacher and the group of students that he inspires. This film is an emotional roller-coaster and features subtly brilliant performances from the entire cast. This may very well have been Robin Williams' finest hour. We are given a slew of passionate performances and a truly inspired script which unquestionably deserved the Oscar that year. This film is also a great lesson in independence and free thought. Throughout the course of the film, we see the group of students who re-form the Dead Poet's Society grow from boys into men. They find their own voices and learn to 'seize the day.' A truly powerful and inspiring film and quite possibly on of the best films yet made.

Title: Good
Review: It was a different movie. We can call it a classic right now. They also had good messages. Mr. Williams did a great job. I recommend this movie.

Title: Boy, feeling Joy.
Review:
What's the real meaning here?

That poets and artists should get an equal stage of importance as all other "useful" professions like teachers and scientists? In this age of mass media and art funding they already do!

That people should stand up for their individuality and question authority? In this age of free speech and public debates they mostly do, even if organised violence still counts against unrestricted freedom.

What people have forgotten though, is the permission to enjoy life. This is different to having fun on an ego-trip, or following the common path of profit. Enjoyment requires sincere participation in life and society and reflection upon it's direction. What is the point of life if you can't enjoy it?

The protagonist as a young man drew his legitimate conclusion and unfortunately did not realize his alternatives of overcoming authority. The movie is as much a rare anti-establishment statement as Good Will Hunting (also starring Robin Williams) and as such unmissable, even after all this running time.

Title: poetry, romance, and love are the reasons why we are born human
Review: The opening was exciting, the midfield looked exhausted, and in the end, there was a final victory. In the end, it turned out to be a victory, deeply ingrained in my heart. The murderer is undoubtedly the "captain" who taught his students the pursuit of happiness, but did not teach them resistance. He taught them to become an idealistic poet, but did not teach them the cruelty of reality. The opening chapter full of ideals ends with a tragic event, where ideals eventually return to reality and are constantly suppressed by reality. Finance, engineering, architecture, and computation are certainly important, they are the conditions for our survival; but poetry, romance, and love are the reasons why we are born human.

Title: One of the best Robin Williams has done.
Review:
This is a terrific film with a great storyline about passion, identity, truth and literature, set in the context of an exclusive all boys preparatory school. All English teachers should have the enthusiasm of John Keating, played brilliantly in this film by Robin Williams, who has come upon the tradition bound school with a creative vengeance. What results can be described as educational alchemy- the magic of inspired teaching that allows learning to take place.

Some viewers may find the story line too simplistic and sentimental, but no one should ignore or deny the film's messages, which include the importance of art in enriching life and letting the true self shine forth.

Title: A smorgasbord of bad acting, obnoxious characters and cliched storylines
Review: The doe-eyed camera hog Robin Williams accepts a job at a prestigious school knowing full well that the school's values are in direct contrast to his whimsical hippy-dippy teaching style. In his desperation to be popular, Williams leads his barely distinguishable pupils down a path of dead-end careers, sexual harrassment (Dad, how did you and Mum meet? Well son, she was unconscious and I just started groping her) and academic self-destruction yet still bows out a hero. Possibly one of the most overrated films of the 20th century.

Title: A powerful influencial film
Review: Why are good movies are hidden from the 90's. Here's to a movie that reminds you that words aren't just words. It savors and stays through our bones for the rest of our lives.

Title: wonderful
Review: Carpe diem!!! oh gosh it was the most wonderful extraordinary creation and novel ive ever seen. i felt so many feelings, emotions from this movie. while i was studying for so many years there was the only 1 teacher such as proud teacher John Keat in the movie, i missed the teacher and cried. it shows the inner nature of the boys and enormous faults of the future education system but they love their fooolish system thats the problem in nowadays. even its the movie of 1989. you guys should watch it. ;-)

Title: Cinematic Beauty at Its Finest - One of The Greatest Movie of All Time
Review:
I watched this movie when i was 12 and it brings even the slightlest change into my life. I'm not a type of person who would often willingly rewatched a movie for a second time. But there are a few movies that the more you watch it, the deeper you can appreciate each and every single detail. The more you can see and understand, it's like looking back to your favourite moment of life in the past, over and over. The feeling of comfort.

That's all what Dead Poets Society at least could offer. This will be the number one movie i would say if someone ask me what my favourite movie is.

This movie talks about art, poems, friendship, youth, freedom, and all the great lesson of life. All in one, it's all what my soul longing for.

I have never seen such a movie with a very beautiful cinematography and also a touching, impactful story to tell. Each character has their own special place in my heart (definately except you know who!). Each character has a huge difference from one to another, and i think it's represent the diversity of many souls in the earth. They are all different, yet are all precious. I personally find myself has a big similarity to Todd Anderson. Knowing people had to been through the same thing as you are bring a sense of comfort and the safe feeling of being home. This movie feels like home to me.

Let's talk about what i gained and what opened my eyes from watching this movie.

Tears. Tears. Tears.

An absolute emotional roller coaster. Neil didn't deserves his life to be controlled.

This movie is all what you could ask for--joy, comedy, romance, drama, sorrow-- i cant even find the right words to describe this movie. Very hard. And this is all what i could say, there's still so much thing in my head yet i coudn't make the words out.

I love this so much. You missed so much thing in your life if you havent at least watched this movie once. I'd never getting bored of this, i would not be complained at all if this is the only thing i could watch for the rest of my life.

Title: PERFECTION; RIP ROBIN WILLIAMS
Review:
A timeless classic that every high school English teacher will make you watch. Revisiting this film really makes me miss Robin Williams.

Great character development, a bit slow, but a classic that can't be forgotten.

5/5. RIP Robin Williams.

Title: This Movie Made me Love school so much !!
Review:
This is one of my favorite movies of all time because i watched it when i was 10 years old now I'm 22 years old and re-watched it again! It made me tear up because i remembered ROBIN WILLIAMS great acting in it regarding his broken surprised death This iconic movie should have one an Oscar but at least it got nominated for one

Taught me how to engage with your friends love your teachers and share the things you love .

One of the greatest movies of all time Overall, "Dead Poets Society" is a must-see film that deserves all the praise it has received over the years. It's a poignant and powerful story about the importance of following your passions, challenging the status quo, and living life to the fullest. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend giving it a watch.

Title: Brain jolting, exhilarating
Review:
Certain movies and incidents leave a very deep impression upon you. This is a movie that jolts every corner of your brain and raises questions on the very meaning of the word success which has been stretched too far by the orthodox and out-fashioned minds. It's movie that I wish had a very happy ending instead of an emotional one.

I have always been inspired by the works of Robin Williams and his approach towards mankind. This is his masterpiece, in fact, I would go along with historic performance. Its a movie that in spite of its era continue to relate to individuals at various levels (credits and profound thanks to the writers).

Dead poet's society is more alive than any movie I have ever seen or heard. It forces individuals to come out of their cocoons to be the beautiful wings of glorious imagination.

P.S.- I would rate this movie 11/10 but I gave it 9/10 because I had hoped for a very happy ending. Nevertheless a must watch.

Title: A refreshing if obvious drama.
Review: Dead Poets Society shows the efforts of a filmmaker who has his own loving style in making movies.

Title: best movie ever
Review: There isn't alot to say about this movie other than it is perfect. It is as beautiful to watch as The last Emperor or Room with a view but is even more emotionally powerful than both. Not one of the actors is ever anything less than genuine and believable. The story is compelling and thoroughly easy to get lost in. This is what all movies should aspire to.

Title: Stunning.
Review: Truly one of the best films ever made, not to mention the incredible acting. No words to describe but stunning.

Title: I like everything about this movie; except the movie itself
Review: I like poetry. I like Robin Williams. I like Peter Weir. I like Maurice Jarre. So, I had high hopes for this movie and I have to say I was extremely disappointed. It seems in almost every dramatic or semi-dramatic film that Robin Williams stars in, he plays a victim. I kept waiting for him to be picked on and it sure came. John Seating is a new teacher at a very strict school called Welton. His styles and teaching methods are not what the students are used to and his love for poetry inspires them to reopen an old school club called the Dead Poets Society. At this point, the movie falls downhill. I think the problem is the characters. The director tries to make us love and connect with them, oh how hard he tries. But, oh how much I didn't care by the end. We needed to know more about John Seating's personal life and not just his job. Besides a few good themes scattered throughout, there is not a lot to gain by watching this film.

Title: one of the few movies to make me cry
Review:
As a rule, I don't normally cry at movies, but this one is a genuine tearjerker.

This is one of my favorite movies, because there isn't a whole lot about this movie to dislike. The acting is excellent (especially Robin Williams, who can do dramatic acting almost as well as he can comedic), the story rings true and the dialogue is memorable. A really good film.

Title: The reason why I love movies!!
Review:
It is one of these movies that touches you and makes you reconsider your life. It is astonishing how well these young actors perform, while Robin Williams draws a remarkable path in acting.

If you haven't seen it yet, DO IT. "Dead poets society" could be considered as a must-seen film 🎥🎥

Title: O Captain! My captain!
Review:
Sure, sometimes the movie is on the edge of kitsch but who would have thought beforehand that a movie with a teacher trying to inspire his students for poetry would turn out to be such a success. What's more, the movie has also turned the Horace aphorism "carpe diem" into a term that has found its way into modern language and is widely understood. One has to concede, however, that the movie does not deliver its original meaning, which is more about enjoying life as it is than shaping it to one's favour.

Usually I am not such a big fan of Robin Williams as I am not so fond of clowneries but in this movie, he, as Mr. Keating, was playing the unobtrusive part of his lifetime. This opinion apparently was shared by some colleagues from the show business who in their shows, on the occasion of Mr. Williams's death, climbed up a table just as Mr. Keating did in Dead Poets Society to demonstrate how the change of perspective can alter preconceptions.

Besides, the movie can also be seen as a didactic play on what effects a liberal or a strict education can have on teenagers. It will, hopefully open the eyes of all parents who are convinced to know best what is good for their kids without ever asking the kids what they want. The message of possible disaster, however, does not come across completely convincing since I could not quite understand why Neil felt so trapped since otherwise he was a self-confident young fellow.

Eventually, the movie also perfectly demonstrates how recklessly established systems react on outsiders who question this system and try to change it. In case of any occurrence that puts this system and its stakeholders at risk of lower outside acceptance, a scapegoat is quickly found and removed. By doing so the stakeholders count on the cowardice and fears of its dependents and unfortunately this calculation frequently pays off. So does it in the movie. The final scene with the students climbing up on their desks to demonstrate their solidarity with the scapegoat Mr. Keating makes a good ending but does not change the overall situation. It does demonstrate, however, that Mr. Keating's endeavors to encourage the students to become self-confident, non-conformist members of society have fallen on solid ground, especially with Neil's shy roommate Todd, the first one to stand up for the captain, Mr. Keating. Hence, not all is hopeless and changes for the better are possible 

All these interesting aspects along with the many and so diverse coming-of age character studies of the classmates make it a movie definitely worthwhile seeing. Especially it is quite different from most other films.

Title: Very sad, but good!
Review: This movie was very sad, although I won't say why because then my review won't get posted because of spoilers. However, despite its sadness it's a very good movie that I really enjoyed. I would watch it again, except that I cried so hard at the end that my eyeballs fell on the floor and I had to stick them back in. Obviously to make anyone that sad it had to be very good, which it is. The characters are likeable and the acting is outstanding. One of the best movies I have ever seen, and everyone should see it eventually. Regardless of Roger Ebert and his negative review, the fm is still a classic. If you're wondering whether it's worth it, the answer is: go see it and find out for yourself.

Title: 'O captain my captain.'
Review: I've probably seen this film at least 25 times (probably 20 times in 1989 alone) and the final farewell to Robin Williams at the end still leaves me a blubbering mess. It still stands the test of time and remains my favorite Robin Williams performance. Kudos to Peter Weir. Yes I know it owes a lot to 'Goodbye Mr. Chips' and gets a tad too melodramatic towards the end, but the acting, script,direction and terrific score make this one of the finest movies of the 1980's. As an added bonus - if it encourages young people to seek out such magnificent writers and poets such as Shakespeare, Whitman, Keats and Shelley - well, that alone makes the film worthy of high praise indeed.

Title: Dead boring
Review: I tried to get through this, but I just couldn't. It was really really boring and juvenile. Majority of the film is a bunch of nerdy teens acting immature and being very loud. It reminded me of the goonies. Robin Williams is barely in it, majority of screen time is hogged by the dull Ethan Hawke. Thumbs way down.

Title: To the heart and beyond.
Review:
This is the first review that I'm going to write, and perhaps the only one, for the simple fact that this movie really got to me.

Excellent Robert Leonard's role as Nail, he makes a real beauty connection between him and we as spectator, and showing the spark of light of a positive person. There is nothing to say about the performance of Robin Williams, he was brilliant, always reaching the soul with his dramatic performances. Also very well the rest of the cast, keeping in line and letting us to go deep in the film.

The story tells how a group of young people can be influenced to be much better people than they were, in the spiritual aspect, of course. But it also tells us how passion can be obscured under the strict discipline and how it achieves the destruction of the meaning of life who exists in each of us.

I should say that this should be a obligatory film for both teachers, youth and parents.

I was really touched by this film. If you didn't see Dead Poets Society, do not do like me and wait twenty years for see it. Go and watch it now.

Carpe Diem. 10 of 10.

Title: Not as good as I was told it would be
Review:
The movie was good, but it wasn't as good as I thought it would be.

I thought the teacher would be really inspiring and creative, but Robin Williams just didn't measure up. This is the first movie I've ever with him in it as the protagonist where I didn't think he did a great job with the acting.

I still suggest you see it if you haven't because of all the literary connections and the good message it portrays. Education should be interactive and teachers should engage their students in worthwhile exciting discussions, and these values are definitely shown through Robin Williams' actions throughout the movie.

Title: The Greatest Movie of all time
Review: I think that Dead Poets Society of all time. The acting, cinematography, writing, etc, it's all so amazing. Some of the best performances of the movie are Robin Williams role as John Keating and Ethan Hawke's role as Todd Anderson. Director Peter Weir fabulously directs this film, and it's his best movie in my opinion. The movie also has a very powerful message, (which I will not go into in this review because it will take too long). The movie also has many great quotes like, "Seize the day boys. Make your lives extraordinarily." I also really love the setting of the movie, like the landscape and how it goes throughout different seasons over the length of the film. The ending of the film is also extraordinary, in my opinion it's the greatest film ending. The movie is also well paced and doesn't feel like it drags at any point. All in all this is a masterpiece and if you haven't seen it, you need to watch it.

Title: Close to Excellent
Review:
For me, the two best dramas of the quarter century were made in 1989, the first being Tornatore's 'Cinema Paradiso', the other, this film. Today it's illegal to have a spirit, so do we pursue an artistic life in an age when Art is 200 years dead ? Absolve the painter for the seaman, the musican for the technician ? The theme to this film will span the next 600 years, in that tragic respect it makes this a classic.

I'd like to comment to Robert Lorenz, from Dresden, and anyone who; if posting destroys a film's credibility without giving one to compare it with, in doing so destroy their own. Also to dbdumonteil, who recommended Weir's embarrassing estrofest 'Picnic at Hanging Rock.' No doubt to be a favorite in Ivy/prep circles, this film does under-tone a bit too much for me, and in the music (the 80's being the shift to subtle scores). The Literature profs can tear this up all they like: picking Frost over Byron, not getting to the meat of Shakespeare, yet petty needling whilst crap like 'The Breakfast Club,' and 'The Deerhunter' was made and hailed. Cliché's abounding it's message supporting spiritual individualism sets it above the rest. Casting could have been a little better.

Maybe they meant 'Carpe spiritus' (seize the spirit) instead of 'carpe diem' which better synopsizes this film; a solid script telling us it is better to have attempted to live the life of the artist than to experience it as crude nonevent; always with dire consequence.
